newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, February 18.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, February 18.

text.p: The following are the highlights of stories reported in the Irish press on Tuesday.
The government tightens exchequer purse strings and warns pressure groups they will receive no further cash promises in the countdown to a general election.
Gardai have seized key documents linked to drug trafficking by the gang responsible for the murder of investigative journalist Veronica Guerin.
U.S.-based animal nutrition company Alltech is to set up a base in Co. Meath.
Ulster Unionists are the main beneficiaries as British prime minister John Major wins vital vote in Commons.

The Department of Agriculture has introduced a voluntary vaccination scheme to protect the Republic of Ireland's 400 million Irish pound poultry industry from the spread of Newcastle Disease from Northern Ireland.
Farmers' associations have reacted strongly to Dairygold's decision to slash the price of milk, saying the cut should have been phased in.
Revaluation of the Irish pound has been suggested as a way to deal with the strength of sterling in the European Monetary System.
Irish Permanent's share price is overvalued, bloated by takeover speculation, say some equity analysts.
Irish interest rates should not be cut in an effort to bring the Irish pound into line with European currencies, warn top economists.
